title: Should I learn the Avestan script? - Quora

response.answer_text: You should if you want to.  I think Iran should switch to the Avestan or the Latin script, the Arabic alphabet only has 3 vowels, while the Persian language has 6. As you can see the Arabic alphabet is pretty inconvenient for writing Persian vowels. Also each letter in Arabic has 4 forms: intial, medial, final, and isolate. So switching the alphabet would make it easier for both Persians and non-Persians to learn to read and write. I think it should be taught in schools so kids can grow up writing their language in this new alphabet. Besides Persians are not Arabs, why would they use their alphabet? Also, did you know that Persian is an Indo-European language? That means that Indians and Europeans can learn the language faster than Arabs ever will. But people don’t because they think Persian is similar to Arabic, which is far from true. Some Persians might say that they will lose history by switching alphabets, this is far from true. Consider that Old Persian was written in Cuneiform, but no-one is complaining that history has been lost because people don’t learn Cuneiform. Besides if they can read Avestan, they will recover some of their lost history, before the Arabs came to Persia. Wouldn’t that be great? Persian people, you have to choose if you want to switch your alphabet or not, it’s your decision. I think you should do it, because you are not Arabs. Peace.

You probably can’t find anything about it because Iranians (if the script changed at one point) would rather switch to the Latin script than to Avestan. Even if there are people who learn it, I doubt that they are large in numbers. If you want to learn the Avestan script, by all means go for it if interests you in any way - and if you have time, it might be an interesting thing to do. But if you want to learn it because you heard that some Iranians are learning it and you think that Persian might switch to the script one day, then no, it would be pointless.

Yes you should. If you believe even a part of this “persian” fantasy reflected in your question details, you deserve to spend a big chunk of your time on learning a useless, dead language from 3,000 years ago. So do all these other “persians” who are actually doing it, if true. Have fun!

It’s too difficult to learn it, but it will give you an advantage in being able to read Avesta and learn about the first monotheistic religion that became a fountainhead for Islam, Judaism and Christianity. Keep in mind that every vowel has its own distinguished character, and the laws of where to put each character could be rather difficult to understand. I’ve been trying to learn Avestan for the past 3 years and it has just recently become successful. It takes a long time and real dedication to be able to master it. You may start from using this document. That’s where I began my trainings.

The Avestan script is not Persian. Zoroaster was a Kurd from the Kurdistan region now occupied by Iran. Although people call the language in the avesta a “"dead language” , Kurds who can speak the Kurmanji dialect of Kurdish can understand a great deal of it. Avesta is not an Ancient “Persian” language. So I don't know what people you are talking about when you say “Persians”, as the empire no longer exists and it is called Iran. And most modern day Iranians are a mix of different ethnicities, including Baluchi, Lor, Turk, Azeri, Azerbaijani, Armenian , Kurd, etc
